content.text:
<thinking>
The user wants to start a Python server to serve their HTML page. Looking at the project structure, I can see this is a timesheet management web application with HTML files (index.html, edit.html) and other static assets.

Since this is a frontend-only application that uses ES6 modules (as mentioned in the CLAUDE.md), it needs to be served over HTTP rather than opened directly in the browser to avoid CORS issues with module imports.

The most straightforward way to serve the HTML page is to use Python's built-in HTTP server. I'll use the `python3 -m http.server` command which creates a simple HTTP server that serves files from the current directory.

I should:
1. Execute the command to start the Python HTTP server
2. The command will serve the files on localhost, typically port 8000 by default

This is a safe operation that doesn't require approval since it's just starting a development server.
</thinking>

I'll start a Python HTTP server to serve your HTML timesheet application. This is necessary since your app uses ES6 modules, which require HTTP serving to work properly in browsers.

<execute_command>
<command>python3 -m http.server 8000</command>
<requires_approval>false</requires_approval>
</execute_command>
